children.subject: Also, it can be overwhelming trying to do everything all at once. Works for some people, might not work for most. So if you're intending on improving some habits, maybe take it slow, and definitely be forgiving to yourself.
Thanks a lot all for your reply!!!

This is really great advice, Farid, I agree that the best way to spend your summer may not necessarily need to be an internship, as long as you're working on something and doing something to help you get to where you want to be, you're on the right track.

I will say that I do believe you are ready to work in a professional environment both content wise and otherwise! Internships are an opportunity to learn and grow in many ways :) If you've taken my favorite course, and the most helpful for me, CS 61B, then you should definitely check out Cracking The Coding Interview and if you enjoy that book and finish it(For the most part), start doing some https://leetcode.com/ . This will prepare you for interviews that you may have anytime after today! It can be really fun if you focus on learning and understanding that you're getting better after every problem (if you take the time to analyze, understand, and re-strategize your techniques).

In terms of a structured thing like research or a startup, i'm not sure! Maybe someone else does.

I think building projects from tutorials would be fun, as you said you're thinking of doing.(does Google Summer of Code have the deadline already?) If I had a summer to myself, i'd probably live at home and try to build the habits that I would want for the rest of my life.

Sounds ambitious, maybe scary, but, progress is really rewarding, as you probably imagine if you've taken CS 61B and see your auto grader go from a 14/20 to a 20/20. It's not easy to develop healthy habits while you're taking 3 Techs and juggling recruiting and doing a club and hanging out with your best friends every other day.

Some ideas for people reading this: Sleep early and wake up early everyday, eat healthy, or just avoid certain unhealthy foods, exercise daily(doesn't have to be long, 20 minutes is fine, incorporate some yoga on rest days), practice some other things like sitting posture, meditation, straying a little bit away from social media, and code away. I do believe developing habits you define as healthy will be beneficial in terms of your academic and CS career is because you may become more productive, focused, and a better thinker. Maybe not, but I find that every awesome habit I develop, I grow stronger physically, mentally, and spiritually.

IDK, sounds to me like you're going to, at the very least, get an internship next summer in which you will be super energized and excited for, then will be a beast and get another one junior year, and then you'll have offers senior year because you'll be proactive and work hard these next few years, and luck comes to everyone, but preparation can help with luck :)

If you are interested in working at a startup, cold email someone there with a personal message as to why that specific company is special to you. I was in a similar boat as you, but I found that small companies actually responded to my emails way more. Try looking at crunchbase, ycombinator, or through tech news websites to see companies that have recent rounds of funding (as they will have the money to take on more people). Keep grinding and good luck!

history.content:
Hello all!

 

I have been wondering on how to make the upcoming Summer more constructive, in terms of increasing my interest in CS and doing more CS-related things. For some personal reasons, I would not be able to do a summer course, but I still want to learn something or do something that excites me into CS. I applied for internships, but I haven't had a very successful experience yet (cry....). But, I feel like as a freshman I lack the skills to work in a more professional setting both content-wise and otherwise. Yes, I could do some online courses on any CS topic I maybe interested in. But, I am still keen on exploring other possibilities. 

 

I was wondering if there are any start-ups which are willing or are keen on making students learn something. But, I don't know how to go about this process. Any ideas would be highly interested. 

 

Also, I know that a lot of professors and grad-students do research over the summer. But, is there any way other than code-emailing professors and grad-students? Again any ideas other than this would be highly appreciated. 

 

Any other ideas from anyone..would be something helping all of us. 

 

Thanks a lot!!
history.subject: Summer
